frontmatter.title: 5. Connect your API to a client
frontmatter.description: Hook up your graph to Warthog Client

children.value: The next half of this tutorial exclusively focuses on connecting a graph API to a frontend with Warthog Client.

is a complete data management solution for any client. It's view-layer agnostic, which means it can integrate with React, Vue, Angular, or even vanilla JS. Thanks to its intelligent cache, Warthog Client offers a single source of truth for all of the local and remote data in your application.

While Warthog Client works with any view layer, it's most commonly used with React. In this section, you'll learn how to connect the graph API you just built in the previous half of this tutorial to a React app. Even if you're more comfortable with Vue or Angular, you should still be able to follow many of the examples since the concepts are the same. Along the way, you'll also learn how to build essential features like authentication and pagination, as well as tips for optimizing your workflow.

properties.ariaLabel: set up your development environment permalink

While Warthog VSCode is not required to successfully complete the tutorial, setting it up unlocks a lot of helpful features such as autocomplete for operations, jump to fragment definitions, and more.

Our key is now stored under the environment variable

Next, create an Warthog config file called

Great, we're all set up! Let's dive into building our first client.

Before we show you how to use the React integration for Warthog, let's send a query with vanilla JavaScript.

and you should see an object with a
property containing the result of our query. You'll also see some other properties, like
. This is because Warthog Client tracks the loading state of your query for you.

Warthog Client is designed to fetch graph data from any JavaScript frontend. No frameworks needed. However, there are view layer integrations for different frameworks that makes it easier to bind queries to the UI.
